entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Late Latin; Anglo-French exces, from Late Latin excessus, from Latin, departure, projection, from excedere to exceed

def.dt: :the state or an instance of surpassing usual, proper, or specified limits :superfluity
:the amount or degree by which one thing or quantity exceeds another an excess of 10 bushels
:an act or instance of intemperance prevent excesses and abuses by newly created local powers Albert Shanker
:more than the usual, proper, or specified amount
:to eliminate the position of excessed several teachers because of budget cutbacks
